article.body: Negotiators for the U.K. and the European Union started a new round of intensified trade talks on Wednesday, aiming at striking a deal on their tough, 10-months-long negotiations before a crucial summit of EU heads of states and governments on Oct. 15. â¢ In a sign of concession from London, chief U.K. negotiator David Frost told the House of Lords that the government would consider going âfurther than you normally do in a free-trade agreementâ on the crucial questions of state aid rules and regulations. â¢ Cabinet office minister Michael Gove opined that the way the talks have evolved in the last few weeks is âcause for steady optimism.â He added that he now saw the odds for a deal at 66%. â¢ Both U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson and EU Council President Charles Michel said after a phone conversation on Wednesday that a deal would be preferable for both camps. â¢ Bank of England Gov. Andrew Bailey said in an interview that the two sides should be able to strike a deal, if only because âit is in the interest of both sides â letâs be blunt â to get an agreement.â In a separate intervention before an EU panel on Thursday, Bailey acknowledged that the post-Brexit transition âwould have been easier had we not have to deal with COVID.â Opinion: The U.K. economy was crippled before the virus hit. More reason for the government to be careful about Brexit The outlook: Both camps acknowledge that âsignificant differencesâ remain on both the state aid and the fisheries questions. The upbeat mood does signal a change of tone compared with the previous weeksâ acrimony. But in the last months, sudden warnings or ultimatums have often followed days of cautious optimism. The EU launched a legal procedure last week against the U.K.âs recent âinternal market bill,â which reneges on key aspects of the withdrawal agreement and its protocol on Ireland signed by the two sides last year. Before a deal can be struck, it may require the EU leadersâ ultimate green light next week, which would then lead to both sides rushing to claim major political victories, however serious or flimsy the evidence.
